author: By The New York Times
title: Readers in Asia: What Does L.G.B.T.Q. Life Look Like Where You Live?
description: We may include your response in a June edition of the Asia Pacific Morning Briefing.
content: Many countries celebrate Pride in June, recognizing L.B.G.T.Q. people and their struggles for equality around the world. But that fight, and that celebration, look different in different places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Pride Month in New York Is Back. Here’s How to Celebrate.
description: Indulge in gay nostalgia with Christina Aguilera and Junior Vasquez, see Billy Porter march, or dance the night away at Body Hack.
content: New York City’s official Pride theme this year is Strength in Solidarity, an apt reminder that Pride was born as a protest movement against bigotry wherever it manifests. Not that there isn’t room to party, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: Why Are Remote Corporate Workers Having More Fun? Co-Working Spaces.
description: For many, shared offices have become an escape from often chaotic homes — and a chance to join a community. Are they the future of co-working?
content: Before the coronavirus pandemic, Andrew Slaughter started his workday battling morning traffic — generally between 15 to 40 minutes — on the way to the LabCorp office in the Research Triangle Park of Durham, N.C., where, as a proposal manager, he puzzled out lab service costs associated with clinical trials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: A Composer Shifts Her Focus to Climate, With Help From Children
description: Julia Wolfe’s latest in a series of increasingly political, oratorio-like works, “unEarth,” premieres this week at the New York Philharmonic.
content: Julia Wolfe, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer and co-founder of Bang on a Can, has a way with words.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Morgan Wallen, Indie Sleaze and ‘Survivor’
description: Introducing a new weekly video show from the Popcast team that breaks down the essential pop culture story lines of the moment.
content: Welcome to Popcast (Deluxe), a new weekly video show hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli that breaks down essential pop culture. This week’s episode includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: How to Lower Deaths Among Women? Give Away Cash.
description: Mortality rates fell by 20 percent among women in countries that began cash transfer programs to the poor. Children also benefited.
content: Cash grants made directly to poor families or individuals have led to fewer deaths among women and young children, according to a new analysis of more than 7 million people in 37 countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Carlos Prieto, Stella Tan, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rikki Novetsky, Rachel Quester, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: Republicans Impeach One of Their Own
description: In Texas, the impeachment of the state attorney general, Ken Paxton, highlights tension over the future of the Republican Party.
content: Since 2016, the cardinal rule of Republican politics has been to defend Donald J. Trump and his allies at all costs, no matter the allegation. That appeared to change last week, when Texas lawmakers issued 20 articles of impeachment against their state’s attorney general, Ken Paxton, a powerful Trump supporter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso’ Finale Recap: Family
description: In an episode that felt very much like a series conclusion, Ted does what he has to do, Richmond plays for a title, and Rebecca finds what she has been waiting for.
content: And so it ends, after three seasons of uplift and heartbreak, corner kicks and penalties, crummy dads and supportive moms, goofy aphorisms and movie references. But mostly uplift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: ‘False Alarm’ in South Korea
description: Also, military tensions in the Arctic.
content: When North Korea launched a rocket carrying its first military reconnaissance satellite yesterday, it triggered evacuation alerts in South Korea that were followed shortly after by a new wave of messages saying that the earlier notice was a “false alarm.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Packing Figures and Charts, Roy Leads G.O.P. Revolt Against Debt Limit Deal
description: The Texas Republican, who is the policy director for the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, has become the face of Republican opposition to a compromise forged to avert a federal default.
content: At the height of Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s quest for his post in January, Representative Chip Roy, Republican of Texas, darted from meeting to meeting ensuring that hard-line conservatives got what they wanted before agreeing to back the California Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Simply Be
description: Brandon Koppy wants us to use our instincts.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun, Victoria Kim and Jin Yu Young
title: Seoul Awoke to a Dire Alarm: ‘Prepare to Evacuate.’ Whoops.
description: South Koreans said the alert, which was triggered by a North Korean rocket launch, showed that their country was unprepared to respond to a real emergency.
content: SEOUL — The emergency siren began wailing at 6:32 a.m. Several minutes later, personal cellphones around Seoul were screeching with a government alert urging residents to “prepare to evacuate,” children and the old and weak first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Adds Aid to Ukraine to Deliver Ammunition for Drones and Artillery
description: The move to send $300 million in additional support comes as Moscow has come under drone attacks in recent days.
content: The Biden administration on Wednesday announced $300 million in military aid for Ukraine, the latest package of weapons and other military equipment that the United States has been sending to Kyiv since the beginning of Russia’s invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
title: A Desperate Act Reveals the Dwindling Room for Dissent in India
description: Their protest dispersed, female wrestlers who have accused a powerful official of sexual harassment went to the Ganges intending to throw away their Olympic medals.
content: The Olympic wrestlers arrived on the banks of the sacred river Ganges late on Tuesday for what they had announced as a final act of desperation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: A Singer Returns to Shore at the Met in ‘Dutchman’
description: After a triumphant house debut in 2019, the bass-baritone Tomasz Konieczny brought power and clarity to the title role in “The Flying Dutchman.”
content: On Tuesday night, four years after being hailed as the breakout star of a revival of Wagner’s “Ring” at the Metropolitan Opera, Tomasz Konieczny returned there to headline “Der Fliegende Holländer,” or “The Flying Dutchman.” It was worth the wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Honoring the Body Donors Who Are a Medical Student’s ‘First Patient’
description: Gratitude ceremonies give students and faculty members a chance to recognize the sacrifice of those who gave their bodies for medical research and education, and the loved ones they left behind.
content: A solemn gathering at Columbia University last month had the trappings of a traditional memorial service. Students and faculty members performed music and gave speeches. The university’s chaplain closed the ceremony with a reflection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: These Make-Ahead Ribs Are Perfect for Summer Parties
description: You don’t need a grill for Millie Peartree’s new recipe.
content: “You don’t always have to grill when we ‘throw something on the grill.’” This from Millie Peartree in a New York Times Cooking YouTube video, where she proves her point with a fantastic new recipe for oven barbecue ribs, made in the kitchen start to finish. The recipe combines a dry rub with barbecue sauce to get the richest, most intense flavor from falling-off-the-bone tender meat. Make sure to watch Millie in action. She’s a delight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ralph Vartabedian
title: A Poisonous Cold War Legacy That Defies a Solution
description: A $528 billion plan to clean up 54 million gallons of radioactive bomb-making waste may never be achieved. Government negotiators are looking for a compromise.
content: From 1950 to 1990, the U.S. Energy Department produced an average of four nuclear bombs every day, turning them out of hastily built factories with few environmental safeguards that left behind a vast legacy of toxic radioactive waste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: As Iran Seizes Tankers in Gulf, U.A.E. Pulls Back From U.S.-Led Maritime Force
description: The United Arab Emirates announced it had stopped participating in the security group after Iran seized two tankers in the Persian Gulf recently.
content: The United Arab Emirates announced on Wednesday that it had stopped participating in a maritime security force led by the United States, the latest hint of tensions between Washington and key Persian Gulf allies who complain that America has not done enough to protect them from Iranian threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
title: India Is Scrapping Its Largest Bill. The Race Is On to Spend It.
description: The move to retire 2,000-rupee notes, worth $24, has triggered bad memories of a similar campaign in 2016. It has also left some businesses short of change.
content: Indians have been filing into gas stations, jewelry stores, fruit stands and any other businesses that still accept soon-to-be-withdrawn 2,000-rupee notes, each worth about $24.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney, Joshua Barone and Javier C. Hernández
title: Departures Force Los Angeles Philharmonic to Reinvent Itself, Again
description: Its beloved music director, Gustavo Dudamel, is leaving for New York, and its innovative chief executive, Chad Smith, is going to Boston. Now the esteemed orchestra is pondering what’s next.
content: One of the most significant developments in American classical music so far this century has been the ascendancy of the Los Angeles Philharmonic: a showcase of talent, inventive programming and strong finances that has become the envy of other orchestras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Passes Debt Limit Bill in Bipartisan Vote to Avert Default
description: An overwhelming bipartisan coalition pushed through the compromise struck by Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Biden, even as lawmakers in both parties signaled displeasure with the plan.
content: The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly passed legislation negotiated by President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy to suspend the debt ceiling and set federal spending limits, as a broad bipartisan coalition lined up to cast a critical vote to pull the nation back from the brink of economic catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Inside ‘the Hogwarts of Fashion’
description: Most schools rev up for the big game. At the High School of Fashion Industries, it’s the spring fashion show. And this year’s was bigger and sassier than ever.
content: A procession of teenagers with hard-faced stares strutted through an evening rain during a small fashion show in Lower Manhattan, causing a mixture of delight and bewilderment among passers-by who witnessed the spectacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Juan Carlos Formell, Buoyant Heir of Cuban Musical Legacy, Dies at 59
description: The son of Juan Formell, a giant of Cuban music, he found his own voice as a singer-songwriter. He died during a performance in New York.
content: Juan Carlos Formell, an acclaimed singer-songwriter who settled in New York after defecting from Cuba and eventually took over as bassist for his famous father, Juan Formell, in Los Van Van, one of the most influential bands of post-Revolutionary Cuba, died on Friday during a performance in New York City. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marissa R. Moss
title: After 15 Years, the Nashville Punks Be Your Own Pet Are Roaring Back
description: After a quick rise and a fast burnout, this quartet has regrouped, acquired a fresh perspective, and made a new album, with Jack White’s encouragement.
content: When the mid-aughts punk phenomenon Be Your Own Pet opened for Jack White in Nashville last spring, it was the first time that Jemina Pearl’s 5- and 10-year-old children, Lula and Elvis, had seen their mother in full rock ’n’ roll glory: split-kneed on the ground in metallic blue pants, singing songs about zombies to a screaming, enraptured crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump White House Aides Subpoenaed in Firing of Election Security Expert
description: The special counsel is scrutinizing the dismissal of Christopher Krebs, who contradicted baseless claims by the former president that the 2020 election was marred by fraud.
content: The special counsel investigating former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to cling to power after he lost the 2020 election has subpoenaed staff members from the Trump White House who may have been involved in firing the government cybersecurity official whose agency judged the election “the most secure in American history,” according to two people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Mississippi Is Offering Lessons for America on Education
description: The state shows that poverty is no excuse for failing to teach kids to read.
content: JACKSON, Miss. — The refrain across much of the Deep South for decades was “Thank God for Mississippi!” That’s because however abysmally Arkansas or Alabama might perform in national comparisons, they could still bet that they wouldn’t be the worst in America. That spot was often reserved for Mississippi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: 14th Amendment Questions Linger Despite Debt Limit Deal
description: President Biden has been considering ways to challenge the constitutionality of the debt limit to defuse the risk of default.
content: The agreement President Biden struck with House Republicans to raise the debt limit aims to avert a catastrophic default on the nation’s debt. But the brinkmanship that brought the United States within days of being unable to pay its bills has renewed calls for the Biden administration to stop the debt ceiling from continuing to be a political tool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Rise in Sightings of Honeybee Swarms Has U.K. Beekeepers Scrambling
description: It’s swarming season in Britain, with honeybee colonies splitting in half in search of new homes. This year, beekeepers say they are getting an unusually high number of swarm sightings.
content: The sight is one that beekeepers say is understandably intimidating to the ordinary person out for a walk: a sliver of sky suddenly darkening amid the collective roar of thousands of honeybees before they cluster on branches or bushes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Drone attacks on Moscow.
content: A number of attack drones were downed over Moscow yesterday, the first time civilian areas of the Russian capital had been touched directly by the Ukrainian conflict and a signal that a distant war might soon begin to feel somewhat less so for ordinary Russians. Apartment windows were shattered, and there were some minor injuries in one neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: A Vintage Store That’s ‘Curated for Curves’
description: With Berriez, Emma Zack hopes to change the fashion market for plus-size shoppers.
content: Susie Mensah tried on a lilac crochet dress in a corner of a shop called Berriez, then posed as her friends and the shop owner met her with oohs of approval, the way friends do when an outfit looks really, truly good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Was Taped Discussing Sensitive Document He Had Kept After Leaving Office
description: Federal prosecutors obtained the recording as part of their investigation into the former president’s handling of classified documents.
content: Federal prosecutors investigating former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified material have a recording of Mr. Trump from 2021 discussing a sensitive military document he had kept after leaving the White House, two people briefed on the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: How to Be a Star by Not Giving Your All
description: She’s known for playing offbeat characters in “Russian Doll,” “High Maintenance” and “Girls,” but Greta Lee is winning raves for her restrained performance in “Past Lives.” It almost didn’t happen.
content: Greta Lee shines at playing the entrancing oddball, the scene-stealing weirdo you can’t take your eyes off of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany closes Russian consulates in a tit-for-tat dispute with Moscow.
description: Berlin responds to the Kremlin limiting the number of German diplomatic staff allowed in Russia.
content: Berlin is ordering four of the five Russian consulates in Germany to close after Moscow limited the number of German diplomatic staff allowed in Russia, the latest in an escalating tit-for-tat diplomatic dispute between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Vote on the Debt Deal
description: Also, uninsurable climate risks. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: The House will vote tonight on a bipartisan plan to suspend the nation’s debt ceiling for two years and limit spending as lawmakers race to act before a looming default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Adidas Starts Unloading Its Yeezy Gear, to Benefit Anti-Hate Groups
description: The sportswear company, which cut ties with Kanye West over his antisemitic remarks, will donate proceeds from its $1.3 billion inventory of Yeezy-brand sneakers and other goods.
content: Adidas is going to start selling the first pairs of its leftover Yeezy sneakers, a step toward resolving a $1.3 billion inventory headache that has plagued the sportswear company since it severed ties with Kanye West, the rapper known as Ye, over a string of antisemitic remarks by the musician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: In ‘Fancy Bear Goes Phishing,’ Tales of Harmful Hacks
description: A new book by Scott J. Shapiro, a law and philosophy professor at Yale, examines breaches of cybersecurity and their implications for keeping information safe.
content: Don’t let the adorable title fool you: As Scott J. Shapiro acknowledges in “Fancy Bear Goes Phishing,” his new book about cybersecurity, hacking can inflict terrible harm. Shapiro is the author, with Oona A. Hathaway, of “The Internationalists” (2017), which recounts 20th-century efforts to outlaw war; among the numerous questions animating “Fancy Bear Goes Phishing” is whether hacking has opened the door to war by other means.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: JPMorgan Tries to Deflect Blame for Long Relationship With Jeffrey Epstein
description: Depositions from the bank’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, and another top executive paint a picture of leaders who rarely communicated about Mr. Epstein.
content: Two of the highest-ranking executives at JPMorgan Chase pointed fingers elsewhere and denied having had knowledge of Jeffrey Epstein’s long history of sexually abusing teenage girls and young women, as they sought to deflect accusations that the bank ignored multiple warnings about the disgraced financier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Coming to City Center: ‘Pal Joey,’ ‘Titanic’ and the 20th Fall for Dance
description: Also among next season’s highlights: Encores! revivals of “Once Upon a Mattress” and “Jelly’s Last Jam,” and dance works from Pam Tanowitz and Lyon Opera Ballet.
content: Concert re-stagings of “Titanic,” “Once Upon a Mattress” and “Jelly’s Last Jam”; the unveiling of a previously announced rewrite of the Rodgers and Hart musical “Pal Joey”; and dance works by Lyon Opera Ballet and Pam Tanowitz: New York City Center has announced plans for an ambitious 2023-24 season, one in which it will celebrate its 30th Encores! series and the 20th Fall for Dance festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Hunter Biden’s Lawyers Cite Landmark Gun Ruling in Bid to Stave Off Charges
description: Hunter Biden’s legal team is invoking a Supreme Court decision his father has denounced as an affront to “common sense and the Constitution.”
content: To Hunter Biden’s father, the Supreme Court decision last June that expanded Second Amendment rights is a travesty for gun control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson and Julia Moskin
title: James Beard Foundation, Whose Awards Honor Chefs, Is Now Investigating Them
description: The group behind “the Oscars of the food world” created a new process to weed out nominees with problematic pasts. But that process has troubles of its own.
content: The chef Sam Fore received an ominous voice mail message this month from an unknown number. The caller identified himself as a private investigator working for the James Beard Foundation. Later that day, Ms. Fore found herself on a Zoom call, answering questions from him and another man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: At the French Open, Djokovic Storms the Court and Into Controversy, Again
description: In recent days, the Serbian tennis star Novak Djokovic has inserted himself into the mounting international crisis in Kosovo.
content: After everything that Novak Djokovic had put himself through over the past few years, the French Open began with the possibility, finally, of a Grand Slam tournament free of drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: The District Gained Republicans. Could a Liberal Democrat Take It Back?
description: Sue Altman, the leader of a progressive organization in New Jersey, announced Wednesday that she would run for the House seat currently held by Representative Tom Kean Jr., a Republican.
content: New Jersey’s Seventh Congressional District was redrawn last year specifically to boost the chances of Republicans. It worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: A Teenager and Two Boys, 8 and 9, Are Fatally Shot in Pennsylvania
description: A 33-year-old man was also injured in the shooting outside of a house in Lebanon, Pa., about 80 miles northwest of Philadelphia, the police said.
content: A 19-year-old man and two boys, ages 8 and 9, were fatally shot outside a house in Lebanon, Pa., on Tuesday night, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Russia Denounces West Over Drone Strike on Moscow
description: Kremlin officials said Ukraine’s allies should have condemned the strike, and argued again that its real war was with the West.
content: A day after a drone strike on Moscow, Kremlin officials jumped on the refusal of Ukrainian allies to denounce the attack as proof that Russia’s real war was with the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle, Jill Cowan and Ivan Penn
title: Climate Shocks Are Making Parts of America Uninsurable. It Just Got Worse.
description: The largest insurer in California said it would stop offering new coverage. It’s part of a broader trend of companies pulling back from dangerous areas.
content: The climate crisis is becoming a financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Vandal Causes $250,000 in Damage to ‘Jurassic Park’ Exhibition, Police Say
description: At the show in Atlanta, based on the series of dinosaur films, a man was caught on video on top of one of the beasts, ripping off its skin. He was later arrested.
content: A newly opened dinosaur exhibition in Atlanta based on the blockbuster series of “Jurassic Park” movies has been temporarily shut down after an intruder broke in and caused $250,000 in damage, the police said. One man is in custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in New Hampshire, Colorado and the District of Columbia
description: A 1720 Colonial in Newton, a renovated farmhouse in Glen Haven and a three-bedroom condominium in Washington.
content: This house was built for Captain Joseph Bartlett, the father of Josiah Bartlett, a New Hampshire delegate to the Continental Congress who signed the Declaration of Independence. Over the last 300 years, it has been expanded and creatively updated: The root cellar, for example, now serves as a wine room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: As Cable Model Struggles, M.L.B. Takes Over Padres Broadcasts
description: M.L.B. will retain San Diego’s broadcast team and will offer in-market streaming with no blackouts after Bally Sports failed to meet its financial commitments.
content: In a move that could signify the beginning of a new era in how Major League Baseball games are distributed, the league is taking over production and distribution of all San Diego Padres games starting with the team’s game against the Miami Marlins on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: San Francisco’s Ousted District Attorney Has a New Job
description: A conversation with Chesa Boudin, who was rejected by voters last year, as he steps into a new role this week at U.C. Berkeley.
content: It was almost a year ago that San Francisco voters ousted their liberal district attorney, Chesa Boudin, in a recall election, as public frustration was growing over property crime and the visible despair and squalor on city streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
title: Pakistan’s Powerful Military Faces New Resistance From Courts
description: Long seen as kowtowing to the military, the judiciary has defied it in recent rulings, signaling an important shift in Pakistan’s political landscape.
content: For most of Pakistan’s eight-decade history, its courts were largely aligned with the country’s powerful military. They gave three coups a legal stamp of approval, disqualified dozens of politicians who had fallen out of favor with the generals, and turned a blind eye to the disappearances of political dissidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: German Court Convicts 4 Leftists in Attacks Targeting Neo-Nazis
description: A 28-year-old woman and three accomplices were sentenced to prison for their roles in a series of attacks on people they considered neo-Nazis.
content: A German court on Wednesday convicted a 28-year-old woman and three accomplices of organizing and carrying out brutal attacks against people they perceived to be neo-Nazis, in what experts have described as an uncommon case of left-wing extremist violence in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Create a Private Social Space, Far From the Maddening Crowd
description: Alternative apps and shared photo albums let you set up your own exclusive club for online conversations and digital pictures.
content: Even before the recent TikTok bans and mental-health concerns from the surgeon general, public attitudes toward social media have evolved. Many people are moving to online communities on less-populated networks like Nextdoor to get away from the overload of influencers, advertisers, data-mining and political divisiveness that often dominate the larger mainstream platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery
title: Texas Governor Names Interim Attorney General After Paxton Impeachment
description: Gov. Greg Abbott chose John Scott, a former deputy attorney general, to head the office while Attorney General Ken Paxton faces impeachment charges.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Wednesday named John Scott, a longtime ally and a former Texas secretary of state, to serve as an interim replacement for the suspended attorney general, Ken Paxton, while Mr. Paxton faces trial in the State Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Why Chick-fil-A Is Drawing Fire Over a ‘Culture of Belonging’
description: The fast-food chain, once a darling of conservatives, has joined other corporations in pursuing diversity, equity and inclusion policies, prompting some on the right to accuse it of going “woke.”
content: Chick-fil-A drew fierce criticism this week from conservatives calling out the fast-food chain for its diversity, equity and inclusion policy and questioning the hiring of an executive to be in charge of such efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Sick Workers Tied to 40% of Food Poisoning Outbreaks, C.D.C. Says
description: To combat outbreaks at restaurants and other dining establishments, policies that support sick workers, including paid leave, may be needed, the agency said in a report this week.
content: People who showed up to their restaurant jobs while sick were linked to 40 percent of food poisoning outbreaks with a known cause from 2017 to 2019, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a report released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: How Angela Paxton Could Help Decide the Fate of Her Embattled Husband, Ken
description: In Ken Paxton’s impeachment trial this summer, 31 state senators will decide whether to permanently remove him as Texas attorney general. One is his wife.
content: Last September, a process server arrived at the home of Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, as part of a lawsuit filed by groups trying to help women get abortions out of state. Mr. Paxton’s wife, State Senator Angela Paxton, greeted him at the door and told him her husband was on the phone. Later, Ms. Paxton was seen out in the driveway, firing up a pickup truck and swinging open a rear passenger door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elamin Abdelmahmoud
title: Ted Lasso, and the Fantasy of Soft Masculinity
description: A fan-favorite show wraps up a series in which the mostly male characters became more vulnerable, empathetic and comfortable being themselves with other men.
content: The opening credits of “Ted Lasso” aren’t subtle. The titular character wanders through a row of seats in an empty stadium, and as he sits down, his chair and those around it begin to change color, transformed by Ted’s presence. It’s so on the nose that it’s either charmingly winsome or tediously saccharine, depending on your disposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Chelsea Says Executive Accused of Bullying Has Left the Club
description: A Premier League team confirmed the departure after an investigation into workplace behavior, but employees said they had received little information about its findings.
content: Almost a year after one of England’s richest and most decorated soccer teams opened an investigation into a senior executive accused of workplace bullying so severe that several staff members said colleagues took mental health leave to escape it, the team, Chelsea F.C., confirmed that the executive has left the club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Job Openings Rose in April, Defying Cooling Trend
description: The Labor Department report may put pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates further to stem inflation.
content: After three consecutive months of declines, job openings jumped in April, reaching 10.1 million, the Labor Department reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: How Much Does the Debt Limit Deal Save? It’s Complicated.
description: The Congressional Budget Office score does not include side deals hashed out between the Biden administration and Speaker McCarthy.
content: A crucial question for the bipartisan debt-limit deal is deceptively complicated: How much would it actually reduce federal spending?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Larger Screens, Heated Seats, Sushi: Theater Owners Want You Back
description: After scraping by during the pandemic, cinemas are hoping to lure back moviegoers by spending millions of dollars on upgrades.
content: More than three years after the pandemic slammed movie theaters, reducing the flow of new films and keeping patrons away, operators hope a slew of wide releases this summer will finally get those who have grown accustomed to streaming movies at home back into theaters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: NASA Panel Says Data Problems Make Explaining U.F.O.s Difficult
description: A task force has not found any evidence that unidentified anomalous phenomena represent signs of extraterrestrial visits.
content: Members of a NASA task force that studies unidentified anomalous phenomena, or U.A.P.s, said on Wednesday that they were pushing the government to collect better data to try to find answers for unexplained events that have captured the public’s imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Sunak Still Can’t Put the Johnson and Truss Debacles Behind Him
description: Boris Johnson’s misadventures still make headlines, but Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s bigger problem is high inflation and soaring bond yields reminiscent of those that toppled Liz Truss.
content: LONDON — From the moment Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain took occupancy of 10 Downing Street last October, he has been haunted by his predecessors: Boris Johnson, defenestrated after serial scandals, and Liz Truss, deposed after an ill-fated foray into trickle-down economics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Do We Have to Pay for Our Children’s ‘Platonic Partners’ on Family Vacations?
description: Mindful of costs, a reader wonders whether she and her husband are obligated to extend the same hospitality to their daughter’s best friend as to their son’s partner.
content: When my husband and I married, years ago, we created a blended family of children from our prior marriages. Together, we decided that travel was important to us, and we prioritized it: We stayed in our small house and drove used cars to pay for annual family trips. Now, the children are grown, but we want to continue taking them on vacations. So far, we have included our son’s longtime partner. Our other two children are single, but we have a dilemma with our daughter’s best friend and roommate. Our daughter asked if she could bring her on a recent theater outing. We weren’t enthusiastic about spending $150 on a seventh ticket, but her friend had to work, so it became a nonissue. But what if this comes up on our next family vacation to Ireland? Do we have to pay for her? Are platonic partners on the same level as romantic ones?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: ‘Poison in Every Puff’ Among Warnings to Be Printed on Canadian Cigarettes
description: Tobacco companies must soon label individual cigarettes sold in the country with a health warning, in what Canada is calling a global first.
content: TORONTO — “Poison in every puff.” “Cigarettes cause impotence.” “Tobacco smoke harms children.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 9 Shows and Movies Before They Leave Netflix in June
description: An eclectic mix of titles are leaving the service for U.S. subscribers by the end of the month. Catch them before they’re gone.
content: In the month to come, Netflix in the United States will bid farewell to an eclectic mixture of genre movies, sketch comedy, reality TV and romantic comedies, as well as a beloved family feature and a documentary exploration of a peculiar corner of the entertainment industry. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Ben Protess
title: Prosecutors Scrutinize Handling of Security Footage by Trump Aides in Documents Case
description: Investigators are trying to determine if there was any attempt to obstruct them from getting access to footage from a security camera near the room where classified material was stored.
content: For the past six months, prosecutors working for the special counsel Jack Smith have sought to determine whether former President Donald J. Trump obstructed the government’s efforts to retrieve a trove of classified documents he took from the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.S. Will Require All New Cars to Have Automatic Braking Systems
description: The Transportation Department wants new cars to automatically stop when they detect an accident is likely.
content: The top federal auto safety regulator on Wednesday proposed requiring all new cars and trucks to have automatic braking systems that can prevent collisions, after traffic fatalities have soared in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Politics of Delusion Have Taken Hold
description: The irrational element of partisan hostility has seemingly created a political culture resistant to correction or reform.
content: There are very real — and substantial — policy differences separating the Democratic and Republican Parties. At the same time, what scholars variously describe as misperception and even delusion is driving up the intensity of contemporary partisan hostility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Sweet-Tart Roasted Salmon Is Ready in No Time
description: Paired with red rhubarb, these brilliantly pink fillets are on the table in 25 minutes.
content: It’s easy to forget that rhubarb is a vegetable. Much of the time, you’ll find it buried, like a fruit, under an avalanche of sugar baked into a pie, crumble or cake, or maybe simmered into a compote.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 31, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 31, 2023.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about Canada’s gift of the Hudson’s Bay department store building to a group of First Nations referred incorrectly to the estimated cost of bringing the building up to code. The cost, 111 million Canadian dollars, is equivalent to $82 million, not $8 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Dagres
title: A Rapper’s Detention Shows Iran’s Crackdown Is Failing
description: The imprisoned rapper Toomaj Salehi’s life is in danger as Iran ramps up executions. But the message of his music hasn’t gone away.
content: It was a balmy 1:30 a.m. nearly a year ago in Shahin Shahr, a city in central Iran, and the rapper Toomaj Salehi was sitting on the roof of his apartment building, jotting down some new lyrics. On the street below, he watched as someone emerged from a small, boxy Saipa Pride and started rummaging through a dumpster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Duggar Family and Reality TV’s Exploitation of Kids
description: A disturbing new documentary shows the mistreatment behind a “Shiny Happy” facade.
content: There are so many disturbing moments in the documentary series “Shiny Happy People: Duggar Family Secrets” — about the prolific family behind the saccharine reality TV hits “19 Kids and Counting” and “Counting On” — that it’s difficult to pinpoint the most appalling. Over four episodes, the Amazon Original series, out this Friday, is a perpetual unfurling of abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fulfilled by a Thwarted Succession
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 31, 2023.
content: “Somebody once said that actors are emotional athletes. And this show has been like a decathlon for me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By R. Eric Thomas
title: From Paul Rudnick, a Mismatched Couple but Perfect for Each Other
description: Following a neurotic writer and a wealthy aesthete over four bumpy decades, “Farrell Covington and the Limits of Style” is a gay rom-com that tugs at the heart.
content: Nate Reminger, a New Jersey-born, gay, Jewish and unabashedly horny virgin, shows up at Yale University in 1973 and instantly sets his sights on the one man he’ll be gazing at for the next four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Get Lost in Clay, Even if It’s Just for the Weekend
description: Pottery workshops like those at the Watershed Center for Ceramic Arts in Maine are filling up with people who want to connect with others instead of screens.
content: The challenge: Make 10 small clay objects in 18 minutes — one minute each for the first five pieces, two minutes for the next four and five for the last one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Iiu Susiraja: She Has Issues? No, You Have Issues
description: In her first museum show in the United States, this Finnish artist uses her own XL body to bring a new emotional depth to the genre of setup photography.
content: The strange, discomfiting photographs and videos of the Finnish artist Iiu Susiraja push so many buttons that her provocative exhibition at MoMA PS1 should have been staged in an elevator — to paraphrase the theater critic Peter Marks. These powerful works take aim at a dizzying array of contemporary body image issues, obsessions and taboos, and from different angles, including fat shaming, fitness, obesity, standards of beauty, dysmorphia, self-loathing, self-love and of course sex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Big Day for the Debt Ceiling
description: The bipartisan debt limit deal still isn’t assured of passing.
content: Can House Republicans behave as the members of a well-functioning political party would? Or are they still the same party that has cycled through one House leader after another over the past decade, unable to find one who can unite various factions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Armie Hammer Won’t Be Charged After Sexual Assault Investigation
description: A woman had accused the actor of assaulting and raping her for more than four hours in 2017, but prosecutors said there was insufficient evidence to support the allegation.
content: The actor Armie Hammer will not face criminal charges after a police investigation into a sexual assault allegation against him, the Los Angeles County District Attorney’s Office said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Elyssa Dudley, Hans Buetow, Jen Poyant, Sara Sarasohn, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: We Dated for Three Years. He Forgot It All.
description: When Tyler’s ex-boyfriend Sam gets amnesia, she becomes the keeper of their past.
content: Sam and Tyler’s relationship was built on a philosophy of joy. Together, they climbed trees, ate cream puffs in bed, and danced in a field with their friends. But, after three years together, Sam was no longer in love, and they broke up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Jarvis
title: First Drought, Then Flood. Can the West Learn to Live Between Extremes?
description: When Californians aren’t thirsting for water, they’re drowning in it. But experts see a way to navigate climate swings.
content: The shadows were long and the wind across the flatlands fierce as trucks and ATVs began pulling into Chepo Gonzales’s yard one afternoon this March. “Did you double up your socks today?” Gonzales teased one of the arrivals, a man who complained about cold feet during the previous night’s patrol. Another man leaned out the window of his truck and offered a more serious status report: “There’s a lot of water out there, but it’s flowing north.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: Stephanie Saul
title: The GRE Test Is Cut in Half: Two Hours and Done
description: Graduate school applicants will take the new version of the standardized test beginning in September, a tacit acknowledgment of its declining relevance in admissions.
content: The GRE, the nearly four-hour marathon of a test that has been the bane of many aspiring graduate students, is being cut in half. It will now take less than two hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Quiet, Please: You Are Not Alone in Your Garden
description: There’s a multicultural world outdoors — and even the gentlest gardeners often disrupt it. Here’s how to avoid that.
content: Spring unfolds each year in color, yes, but also in sound. And, regrettably, in noise — some of it emanating from our gardens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Galaxy Fire Their General Manager, Long a Target of Fan Anger
description: Last in the standings and facing a boycott from fans, the Los Angeles Galaxy ousted Chris Klein.
content: When the world’s most famous soccer player, David Beckham, came to Major League Soccer in 2007, his arrival put the league on the map and affirmed the Los Angeles Galaxy’s status as the young league’s superteam. During Beckham’s tenure, the Galaxy played in three M.L.S. Cups, won two of them and exuded a Hollywood glamour that resonated around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Amazon to Pay $25 Million to Settle Children’s Privacy Charges
description: Regulators said the tech giant kept children’s Alexa voice recordings “forever,” violating a children’s privacy law.
content: Amazon agreed on Wednesday to pay a civil penalty of $25 million to settle federal charges that it kept sensitive information collected from children for years, including their precise locations and voice recordings, in violation of a children’s online privacy law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: We May Be About to Find Out How This Republican Party Really Works
description: There is no obvious question about the country’s fiscal future that the Republican Party’s current policies propose an answer to.
content: If the debt ceiling deal between President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy wins congressional approval, it will tell us a lot about what this Republican Party cares about and how it really works. And it will have proved something important about which lines Democrats can hold and which ones they can’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Who Needs a Dalmatian? This Firehouse Has a Pig.
description: Penny, the unofficial mascot of Engine Company 239 in Brooklyn, is no trouble, as long as the firefighters keep a supply of Cheerios.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll meet the mascot of a Brooklyn firehouse. She’s small and pinkish-white, and she doesn’t have spots like a Dalmatian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: 3rd Man Is Charged With Murder in Killing of Jam Master Jay
description: Jay Bryant is accused along with two other men of fatally shooting the pioneering D.J. of the rap group Run-DMC in his recording studio in 2002.
content: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn on Tuesday charged a Queens man with murder in the 2002 killing of the pioneering hip-hop D.J. Jam Master Jay, bringing to three the number of people accused of taking part in the slaying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiren Lu
title: A Week With the Wild Children of the A.I. Boom
description: In Silicon Valley’s hacker houses, the latest crop of young entrepreneurs is partying, innovating — and hoping not to get crushed by the big guys.
content: The archbishop’s mansion in San Francisco, built in 1904, is now a stately hotel at the northeast corner of Alamo Square Park. Since February, it has been rented out entirely to HF0, or Hacker Fellowship Zero, a start-up accelerator that provides 12-week residencies for batches of fellows from 10 different start-ups. Their experience, which culminates in a demonstration day, is supposed to be the most productive three months of the fellows’ lives. Dave Fontenot, one of HF0’s founders, was inspired by the two years he spent living in monasteries in his 20s: While monastery life was materially ascetic, he found that it was luxurious in the freedom it gave residents to focus on the things that really mattered. And at the Archbishop’s Mansion this year, almost everyone has been monastically focused on what has become San Francisco’s newest religion: artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: emanate
description: This word has appeared in 29 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word emanate has appeared in 29 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 1 in “New Estimate Finds More Magma Under Yellowstone Supervolcano” by Robin George Andrews:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Store Owner Charged With Murdering 14-Year-Old He Wrongly Accused of Stealing
description: Rick Chow, who believed Cyrus Carmack-Belton had stolen four water bottles, chased him out of his convenience store in Columbia, S.C., and fatally shot the boy in the back, the authorities said.
content: A South Carolina convenience store owner has been charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a 14-year-old Black boy whom he falsely accused of shoplifting, chased and shot in the back on Sunday night, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Reality’ Review: An Unusual Suspect
description: A new docudrama starring Sydney Sweeney as Reality Winner is gripping, even as it strips a true story of its political context.
content: Reality Winner’s life changed six years ago in June when F.B.I. agents showed up at her home in Georgia. By the end of the encounter, Winner, who was then a 25-year-old former U.S. Air Force linguist, had been arrested, accused of leaking a top-secret report that included details of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Danny Masterson Is Convicted of Raping Two Women
description: The case against a star of the sitcom “That ’70s Show” drew widespread attention because of accusations that the Church of Scientology had tried to discourage his accusers.
content: A jury in Los Angeles on Wednesday convicted Danny Masterson, the actor best known for his role on the sitcom “That ’70s Show,” of having raped two women in a case that drew widespread attention because of accusations that the Church of Scientology had tried to discourage his accusers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Tara Reade, Who Accused Biden of Assault, Says She Has Moved to Russia
description: Years after accusing President Biden of sexual assault, Ms. Reade told a Russian outlet that she had moved in order to feel safe.
content: Tara Reade, the former Senate aide who accused President Biden of sexual assault as he ran for president in 2020, said on Tuesday that she had moved to Russia and was seeking citizenship there, according to Sputnik, a Russian-government-run news site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Samar Abu Elouf
title: Israel Called Them ‘Precision’ Strikes. But Civilian Homes Were Hit, Too.
description: Palestinians in Gaza say that Israel’s strikes against Islamic Jihad amount to a collective punishment aimed at making them fearful about who their neighbors might be.
content: As the Khoswan family slept, the Israeli military dropped three GBU-39 bombs into their sixth-floor apartment. One of the bombs exploded just outside the parents’ bedroom, leaving the apartment looking as if a tornado had swept through, killing three family members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
description: This month’s selections include a look at a political activist’s life, a reconsideration of a controversial Israeli thesis and a portrait of an author and his editor.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Kim Cattrall Will Make Brief Return on ‘Sex and the City’ Revival
description: The actress, who played Samantha in the original series, had been famously absent from the first season of the reboot, “And Just Like That.”
content: Kim Cattrall, the actress who played the boldly sex-positive Samantha through six seasons and two movies of “Sex and the City” but who has been glaringly absent from the show’s revival, to many fans’ dismay, will appear in one scene of its second season, the streaming service Max confirmed Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Approves Pfizer’s R.S.V. Vaccine for Older Adults
description: Though agency advisers had some safety concerns, the Pfizer shot is expected to be available before the winter R.S.V. season.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved Pfizer’s vaccine against the respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., for adults age 60 and older, the second approval granted for shots offering protection from the virus this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: I Went to China for the First Time in 3 Years, and I Saw Just How Formidable It Is
description: The country’s economic prospects are being underestimated.
content: On my first trip to China in more than three years, I awoke to an uncharacteristically brilliant blue Beijing sky. The forsythia and cherry trees were in full bloom, and the city was sparkling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Melissa Eddy
title: As U.S. Races Ahead, Europe Frets About Battery Factory Subsidies
description: The European Union is trying to assemble the building blocks to produce electric cars, but subsidies are luring companies to the United States.
content: European leaders complained for years that the United States was not doing enough to fight climate change. Now that the Biden administration has devoted hundreds of billions of dollars to that cause, many Europeans are complaining that the United States is going about it the wrong way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Two Ways of Looking at the Stock Market’s Rise
description: Gains have been concentrated in tech, leaving the fate of the rest of the economy open to question.
content: Gains in the U.S. stock market this year have been concentrated among a handful of immensely valuable tech companies. Technology and communications services stocks in the S&P 500 are up more than 30 percent this year to date. Consumer discretionary stocks are up this year as well — by around 18 percent — but all of the other eight S&P 500 sectors are down. Stocks in the energy sector are collectively down more than 10 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: An Appeals Court Gave the Sacklers Legal Immunity. Here’s What the Ruling Means.
description: In return for the shield, the billionaire owners of Purdue Pharma are committed to paying up to $6 billion to help compensate communities and individuals for the ravages of the opioid epidemic.
content: On Tuesday, a federal appeals court granted members of the billionaire Sackler family a legal golden key that they had been seeking for nearly four years: The Sacklers will be shielded from all civil opioid claims related to their company, Purdue Pharma, the maker of the prescription painkiller OxyContin. In exchange, they have agreed to make payments of up to $6 billion to thousands of plaintiffs in now-suspended lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Lincoln Center Names Conductor for Reimagined Mostly Mozart Orchestra
description: Jonathon Heyward will succeed Louis Langrée as music director of the center’s revered summer ensemble.
content: Jonathon Heyward, the rising young conductor who this fall will become the first Black music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, has been tapped to lead Lincoln Center’s summer ensemble, a reimagined version of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, the center announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The Most Common Eating Disorder in the U.S. Is Also the Least Understood
description: Binge eating disorder entered the diagnostic manual on mental health conditions 10 years ago. It’s still getting overlooked.
content: At 2 or 3 a.m., David Tedrow would hide the empty cardboard cereal box, shoving it into the bottom of the trash can or the back of the cupboard, where his wife wouldn’t notice it. Mr. Tedrow was in his 60s and retired, and he often slept until the afternoon so he could stay up late, after everyone else had gone to bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Why Nonprofits Are Moving to Evict Hundreds of Vulnerable Tenants
description: Some of the biggest providers of housing for mentally ill and formerly homeless New Yorkers have sued tenants for unpaid rent. While few have been evicted, critics call the process cruel and unnecessary.
content: One of the largest providers of housing for mentally ill and formerly homeless people in New York City has started hundreds of eviction cases in an attempt to collect millions of dollars in rent that its tenants failed to pay during the pandemic, according to a new analysis of housing court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Wine at Wegmans? Not in New York, if Liquor Stores Can Help It.
description: Despite a state commission’s recommendations, New York lawmakers seem unlikely to make substantive changes to a 1934 law that traces to Prohibition.
content: In New York, all sorts of things that were once considered illegal are now fair game, like buying marijuana and smoking it in public, or betting on sports right from your cellphone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: JPMorgan’s Dimon Denied Having Any Contact With Jeffrey Epstein
description: JPMorgan is being sued over its dealings with Mr. Epstein. In a deposition, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief executive, said he had barely heard of the disgraced financier.
content: When it comes to JPMorgan Chase’s nearly 15-year business relationship with Jeffrey Epstein, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s longtime chief executive, claims to have little firsthand knowledge about the disgraced financier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Ted Lasso’ Taught Phil Dunster How to Play Nice
description: The charismatic English actor, who stars as the cocksure footballer Jamie Tartt, had to trust the writers to transform him from villain to hero.
content: The new Jamie Tartt is very different from the old Jamie Tartt. As played by Phil Dunster, the 31-year-old English actor, the Tartt that closes out the third and probably final season of “Ted Lasso” is earnest, candid and emotionally mature — a far cry from the bratty, egotistic playboy and soccer star we were introduced to in Season 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Ben Protess
title: Trump Asks Judge in Hush-Money Case to Step Aside
description: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said the judge, Juan M. Merchan, has ties to Democratic causes and candidates.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump is asking the judge overseeing his criminal case in Manhattan to step aside, citing ties between the judge’s family and Democratic causes, Mr. Trump’s lawyers said in a statement Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: ‘We Have Fish, That’s Our Currency’
description: Along Ireland’s coast, fishing has been a way of life for generations. But changes to the industry — including a cut in quotas after Brexit and a government plan to scrap boats — may see a way of life disappear.
content: Just before midnight, David O’Neill navigated his trawler into the harbor in Union Hall, a small port in southwestern Ireland, the wake from the vessel sending tiny waves slapping against the pier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Arctic Risks Loom Large as Blinken Tours NATO’s North
description: Russia may be having major difficulties in Ukraine, but it remains a vast power in the north and the Arctic, where climate change is opening new sea routes for trade and trouble.
content: As polar ice melts, Russia, already a major Arctic power, wants to make the region its own. China has ambitions for a “Polar Silk Road.” And NATO is embracing Finland — and Sweden too, Washington hopes — giving the alliance new reach in the Far North.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: How Remote Work Connected Employees Making $19 an Hour and $80,000 a Year
description: At Amazon, warehouse workers have shown support for corporate colleagues, noting they have nothing to gain if office workers lose flexibility that the pandemic proved possible.
content: Eric Deshawn Lerma felt waves of anxiety when he sat down to tally the new costs in his routine since Amazon’s return to the office this spring. There’s parking. There’s fuel. There’s lunch. They add up to at least $200 extra a month, all to support a policy whose justification he can’t fully understand — after three years in which he and his teammates have been doing their jobs from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Higgins
title: Damar Hamlin’s Return to Football Almost Looks Normal
description: The Bills safety participated in drills during the team’s off-season workouts for a second consecutive week and even caught a pass. It was a mundane scene in his surprising return to football.
content: Damar Hamlin was easy to spot on the sideline of the Buffalo Bills’ practice field Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Thomas
title: A Longtime Barman at the Ritz Paris Makes a Clean Dirty Exit
description: Colin Field, who is responsible for cocktails like the Kate 76 and the Clean Dirty Martini, has left his home behind the bar of the cosmopolitan Bar Hemingway.
content: For nearly 30 years, the Bar Hemingway, a 34-seat, oak-paneled hideaway in the Ritz Paris, has been a destination for discerning Parisians and hotel guests in search of a perfect drink prepared by Colin Field, a jovial Briton regarded as one of the world’s greatest bartenders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Our Correspondent on the Drone Strikes in Moscow and Kyiv, and More Stories
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Nicholas Nehamas
title: In Iowa, DeSantis Signals the Start of a Slugfest With Trump
description: After absorbing months of attacks from the former president, the Florida governor is beginning to fire back — but carefully.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida came to Iowa for his first trip as a presidential candidate and made plain that he was done being Donald J. Trump’s punching bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: Daveed Diggs and Awkwafina Discuss ‘The Little Mermaid’
description: An interview with the actors, who have big claws and wings to fill as the voices of Sebastian and Scuttle in the latest live-action version of the movie.
content: He was 7-years-old when “The Little Mermaid” became a surprise animation hit and soundtrack juggernaut in 1989, and she was still a baby. But the Tony-winning “Hamilton” alum Daveed Diggs and the comic actress Nora Lum, who is better known as Awkwafina (“The Farewell,” “Crazy Rich Asians”), both retain vivid memories of the film (the latter fondly recalls it as “definitely a major player in my Disney VHS collection”). Now they’re co-starring in the director Rob Marshall’s ambitious live-action reimagining, currently in theaters: Diggs, 41, as the sympathetic crab Sebastian, and Awkwafina, 34, as the birdbrained gull Scuttle. The pair discuss on-set rap battles, supporting the new Mermaid Halle Bailey and the art of stealing scenes by the seashore. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Can McCarthy Pass the Debt Deal and Keep His Job?
description: The House speaker attempted to strike a careful balance: he could lose conservatives’ votes but could not afford to reach a deal that so infuriated the far right that they would move to oust him.
content: Hard-right lawmakers who have for years resisted increasing the nation’s borrowing limit did not mince words about how they thought Speaker Kevin McCarthy fared during negotiations with President Biden over averting a federal default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: What a New Oral History Reveals About Obama, and the Tradeoffs He Made
description: The first of 470 interviews of Obama administration officials and others involved in the debates of the time offer a fresh inside look at a consequential presidency.
content: On a day of high drama at an international climate change conference early in his administration, President Barack Obama confronted a senior Chinese official who offered what the American delegation considered a weak commitment. Mr. Obama dismissed the offer. Not good enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Oklahoma Supreme Court Rules New Abortion Bans Unconstitutional
description: An older law still prohibits most abortions in the state, but it is less strict about exceptions for medical emergencies.
content: Oklahoma’s Supreme Court said on Wednesday that two laws passed last year that ban most abortions are unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Sudan’s Army Withdraws From Cease-Fire Talks
description: The move deals a blow to efforts to end the war and deliver humanitarian aid to millions of people nationwide.
content: Sudan’s army has withdrawn from talks aimed at achieving a full cease-fire and delivering humanitarian aid across the country, it said on Wednesday, raising the specter of escalating clashes as a war between rival generals rages for a second month in Africa’s third-largest nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Was Queen’s ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’ Originally ‘Mongolian Rhapsody’?
description: One of Freddie Mercury’s early drafts, which is being auctioned by Sotheby’s, shows that he crossed out “Mongolian” and substituted the now-famous title.
content: It’s one of rock’s best-known and strangest songs: a six-minute radio hit that starts out as a piano ballad, becomes a high-pitched opera, then tumbles into a headbanger’s anthem. Queen’s “Bohemian Rhapsody,” released in 1975, sold millions of copies, topped charts and helped redefine what pop music could be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Was an Ex-N.Y.P.D Sergeant a Chinese Agent or an Unwitting Pawn?
description: Michael McMahon faces federal charges with two other men. They are accused of intimidating Chinese citizens in the United States.
content: On a fall day in 2018, two men drove from Brooklyn to a home in a New Jersey suburb. They pounded on the front door. They went to the back deck and peered inside the glass doors. Finally, they taped a note for a former Chinese government official hiding inside with his wife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Florida Art Scammer Sentenced to Over 2 Years in Federal Prison
description: The art dealer, Daniel Elie Bouaziz, 69, was sentenced to 27 months in federal prison for laundering money made selling counterfeit art.
content: A Florida art dealer who promised bargains on works he claimed were originals by master artists including Roy Lichtenstein, Keith Haring and Henri Matisse has been sentenced to more than two years in federal prison for running a counterfeit scheme, federal officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Elif Ince, Safak Timur and Sergey Ponomarev
title: After Erdogan’s Attacks, Fear Spreads Among L.G.B.T.Q. People in Turkey
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan vilified gay people during his re-election campaign, calling them a threat to society and rallying conservatives against them. It has left people feeling threatened, and alone.
content: When Yasemin Oz, a lesbian lawyer in Istanbul, heard President Recep Tayyip Erdogan claiming victory after a runoff election on Sunday, she said she feared for the future. In his speech, he declared “family is sacred for us” and insisted that L.G.B.T.Q. people would never “infiltrate” his governing party.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Christian Cooper and the Birds of New York
description: Readers respond to an essay by a Central Park birder. Also: A worker shortage; wrongful convictions; politicized courts; reparations and tax relief.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Walmart Raises Wages for Some Pharmacists and Opticians
description: The retailer, which sees its health care business as a way to drive profits, is trying to retain workers in a competitive labor market.
content: Walmart, the nation’s largest private employer, said on Wednesday that it was increasing the wages for 7,700 of its pharmacists and opticians, as it expands its health business and seeks to retain the workers in a competitive environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Vivienne Walt
title: Reassessing the Board Fight That Was Meant to Transform Exxon
description: As investors press the oil giant on climate issues, activists say that a hedge fund’s eco-focused victory over the company two years ago has achieved little.
content: At Exxon Mobil’s annual shareholder meeting on Wednesday, activist investors and big shareholders, including Legal & General Investment Management, will take on the company with a series of proxy measures aiming to push it to cut emissions and speed its decarbonization efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Inside Look at Covid’s Lasting Damage to the Lungs
description: This 3-D reconstruction of lung scans reveals damage that has lingered for years in patients who became severely ill early in the pandemic.

title: Fake Signals and American Insurance: How a Dark Fleet Moves Russian Oil
description: The New York Times tracked several oil tankers faking their locations while transporting Russian oil currently under Western sanctions, in an apparent effort to deceive their American insurer.
content: The New York Times tracked several oil tankers faking their locations while transporting Russian oil currently under Western sanctions, in an apparent effort to deceive their American insurer.
